Package com.rb.nonbiz.math.vectorspaces

Class RBMatrix

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.math.vectorspaces.RBMatrix
Direct Known Subclasses:
RBSquareMatrix
public class RBMatrix
extends java.lang.Object
An immutable wrapper around the Colt library's DoubleMatrix2D, in the sense that this doesn't expose any methods that can result in mutating the object, or even expose the matrix itself, where the caller could mutate it.

We don't have 'double' in the name, because we never use floats, and I don't even know if it ever makes sense to have an int. And we certainly don't use complex numbers. So 'double' is implied here.

Note that we do not allow an empty matrix, for error-checking purposes, since our use cases do not need that.

See Also:
RBSquareMatrix

  • Method Details

    • rbMatrix

      public static RBMatrix rbMatrix​(double[][] values)
      Note that we can only instantiate RBMatrix using a 2d array. Although the underlying data structure is a Colt DoubleMatrix2D, it's good to hide that abstraction as much as possible.

    • get

      public double get​(MatrixRowIndex matrixRowIndex, MatrixColumnIndex matrixColumnIndex)
      Returns an element of this matrix based on a row and column index. Throws IndexOutOfBoundsException if either or both indices point to a row and/or column that does not exist.

    • transformCopy

      public RBMatrix transformCopy​(TriFunction<MatrixRowIndex,​MatrixColumnIndex,​java.lang.Double,​java.lang.Double> transformer)
      Apply an arbitrary transform for every element based on its position in the matrix (row and column), and return a copy of this matrix.

      The first two arguments in the supplied TriFunction give the position of the matrix element. The third is the value in the original (not the transformed copy) matrix.

    • multiply

      Multiplies this matrix by another matrix.

      Multiplies this matrix by a RBVector.

    • transpose

      public RBMatrix transpose()
      Matrix transposition

    • inverse

      public RBMatrix inverse()
      Matrix inverse. This simply calls the Colt matrix inverse() function.

      This will throw an exception for singular matrices, as it should; they don't have inverses.

      Warning: this will fail silently for nearly-singular matrices. That is, it will produce an inverse matrix consisting of large almost-balancing positive and negative elements, but the entries will depend very sensitively on the input.

      What you probably want in this situation is to use something like singular value decomposition (SVD) to get a more robust estimate of the inverse.

      Before relying on this inverse, it would be wise to check the "condition number" of the matrix. A condition number much greater than 1.0 indicates near-singularity. Conversely, rotation and permutation matrices have condition numbers of 1.0.

    • calculateDeterminant

      public double calculateDeterminant()
      The name has 'calculate' so it's clear to the caller that the result isn't cached.

      Although a determinant is only applicable to a square matrix, the reason this method does not live in (RBSquareMatrix) is that we want to avoid exposing the underlying DoubleMatrix2D outside this class, because it's a 3rd party class and is not immutable like our own classes, so it's unsafe to do so. Unfortunately, java's 'protected' is not like the C++ 'protected' keyword; it also allows methods and fields to be accessed by other classes in the same package! https://stackoverflow.com/questions/215497/what-is-the-difference-between-public-protected-package-private-and-private-in

    • calculateSingularValueDecomposition

      public RBMatrix.RBSingularValueDecomposition calculateSingularValueDecomposition()

    • copyPart

      public RBMatrix copyPart​(ClosedRange<MatrixRowIndex> rowRange, ClosedRange<MatrixColumnIndex> columnRange)
      Implements the function DoubleMatrix2D, viewPart, from Colt. This returns a new matrix which is a rectangle subset of the current matrix. Note that the colt function itself returns a copy, as of December 2022.

    • copyTopLeftPart

      public RBMatrix copyTopLeftPart​(MatrixRowIndex lastRowInclusive, MatrixColumnIndex lastColumnInclusive)
      Returns a new matrix which is a subset of the current matrix whose top-left item is also (0, 0).

    • toIndexableMatrixWithTrivialColumnMapping

      public <R> RBIndexableMatrix<R,​MatrixColumnIndex> toIndexableMatrixWithTrivialColumnMapping​(ArrayIndexMapping<R> rowMapping)
      This is for cases where we only care about having row keys, but no column keys, i.e. the column keys are just numeric indices for the column, starting at 0.

    • toIndexableMatrixWithTrivialRowMapping

      public <C> RBIndexableMatrix<MatrixRowIndex,​C> toIndexableMatrixWithTrivialRowMapping​(ArrayIndexMapping<C> columnMapping)
      This is for cases where we only care about having column keys, but no row keys, i.e. the row keys are just numeric indices for the row, starting at 0.

    • isSquare

      public boolean isSquare()
      Returns whether or not this matrix is square.

    • getOnlyElementOrThrow

      public double getOnlyElementOrThrow()
      If this is a 1 x 1 matrix, returns the only element. Otherwise, throws an exception.

      The name parallels Iterables.getOnlyElement(Iterable), which has similar behavior.
